title: Why the octopus brain is so extraordinary - Cláudio L. Guerra

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the nervous system of cephalopods like octopuses?

options.label: A
options.text: It is centralized in the brain and has a limited number of neurons.

options.label: B
options.text: It is decentralized in a network of interconnected ganglia with about 500 million neurons.

options.label: C
options.text: It is similar to that of vertebrates and has a rigid skeleton.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not present in the tentacles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the brain-to-body ratio of octopuses compared to other intelligent animals?

options.label: A
options.text: It is lower than that of other intelligent animals.

options.label: B
options.text: It is similar to that of other intelligent animals.

options.label: C
options.text: It is higher than that of other intelligent animals.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not comparable to that of other intelligent animals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the tentacles in an octopus's nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no function and are not part of the nervous system.

options.label: B
options.text: They are controlled by the central brain and have a limited number of neurons.

options.label: C
options.text: They have minds of their own and can think independently.

options.label: D
options.text: They are connected to the central brain but have no autonomy.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the movement of cephalopods like octopuses?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a rigid skeleton and are limited in their movements.

options.label: B
options.text: They have no bones and can bend their limbs at any point and in any direction.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a limited number of joints and are not very flexible.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not able to move at all.

multiple-choice.question: How do cephalopods like octopuses process information and make decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a neurological map of their body and activate specific muscles to respond to stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a behavior library and activate behavioral responses to grab and eat food.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a centralized brain and make decisions based on a limited number of neurons.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no nervous system and do not process information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the signals meeting halfway between the food and the base of the arm in an octopus?

options.label: A
options.text: The arm knows to bend at that spot and grabs the food.

options.label: B
options.text: The arm knows to release the food and moves away.

options.label: C
options.text: The arm knows to move in a different direction and ignores the food.

options.label: D
options.text: The arm does not respond and remains still.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way an octopus's eight arms can think for themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not able to think independently and are controlled by the central brain.

options.label: B
options.text: They can essentially think for themselves and have a high degree of flexibility and creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not able to move at all and are not part of the nervous system.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only able to respond to specific stimuli and have a limited number of neurons.

multiple-choice.question: What has inspired new research in developing flexible robots made of soft materials?

options.label: A
options.text: The study of vertebrates and their rigid skeletons.

options.label: B
options.text: The study of cephalopods and their radically different nervous system.

options.label: C
options.text: The study of mammals and their ability to walk on two legs.

options.label: D
options.text: study of birds and their ability to fly.

multiple-choice.question: What can studying how intelligence can arise along a divergent evolutionary path help us understand?

options.label: A
options.text: More about the evolution of vertebrates and their rigid skeletons.

options.label: B
options.text: More about the evolution of cephalopods and their radically different nervous system.

options.label: C
options.text: More about the evolution of mammals and their ability to walk on two legs.

options.label: D
options.text: More about the evolution of birds and their ability to fly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential of studying cephalopod intelligence and its implications for our understanding of intelligence and consciousness in general?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to a greater understanding of the evolution of vertebrates and their rigid skeletons.

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to a greater understanding of the evolution of cephalopods and their radically different nervous system.

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to a greater understanding of the evolution of mammals and their ability to walk on two legs.

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to a greater understanding of the evolution of birds and their ability to fly.

title: How exposing anonymous companies could cut down on crime - Global Witness

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why anonymous companies exist?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow real people to do business.

options.label: B
options.text: To disguise people doing things they'd rather not have the public know about.

multiple-choice.question: What is a secrecy jurisdiction?

options.label: A
options.text: A place that requires full disclosure of a company's owners.

options.label: B
options.text: A place whose laws allow new companies to be registered with little disclosure about who owns or controls them.

options.label: C
options.text: A place that only allows companies to register with a specific type of ownership.

options.label: D
options.text: A place that doesn't allow companies to register at all.

multiple-choice.question: What can a company based in the U.S. do if it's wholly owned by another company in Liechtenstein?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be listed as the owner of other companies in the U.S.

options.label: B
options.text: It can transfer its ownership to a new company in the U.S.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be listed as the owner of other companies in Liechtenstein.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be dissolved and shut down.

multiple-choice.question: Why do defenders of financial secrecy argue that wealthy individuals need anonymity?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid intrusive media attention and threats to personal security.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid paying taxes and fees.

options.label: D
options.text: To hide their assets may be difficult for authorities to locate or seize.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that anonymous companies are used in economic crimes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are used by corporations evading taxes.

options.label: B
options.text: They are used by rogue governments skirting sanctions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are used by terrorists buying arms.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the difficulties in achieving international cooperation to close the legal loopholes that enable anonymous companies?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of resources and funding.

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of international cooperation and agreement.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that some governments profit from registering anonymous companies.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that some countries have stricter disclosure rules.

multiple-choice.question: What would be the benefit of closing the legal loopholes that enable anonymous companies?

options.label: A
options.text: It would help to reduce corruption and illegal activity.

options.label: B
options.text: It would help to increase transparency and accountability.

options.label: C
options.text: It would help to reduce taxes and fees.

options.label: D
options.text: It would help to create jobs and opportunities.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that anonymous companies are used to launder profits?

options.label: A
options.text: They are used to transfer money to other companies.

options.label: B
options.text: They are used to buy assets and property.

options.label: C
options.text: They are used to create shell companies.

options.label: D
options.text: They are used to transfer money to other individuals.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that corrupt government officials use anonymous companies?

options.label: A
options.text: They use them to award contracts to other companies.

options.label: B
options.text: They use them to transfer money to other individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: They use them to create shell companies.

options.label: D
options.text: They use them to buy assets and property.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that international authorities are working to chip away at the mechanisms that enable anonymous companies?

options.label: A
options.text: They are working to increase transparency and accountability.

options.label: B
options.text: They are working to reduce corruption and illegal activity.

options.label: C
options.text: They are working to require companies to state who ultimately makes their decisions and benefits from their assets.

options.label: D
options.text: They are working to create jobs and opportunities.

title: What’s the difference between a scientific law and theory? - Matt Anticole

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a scientific law and a theory?

options.label: A
options.text: A law is a theory that has been proven to be true, while a theory is a law that has not been proven.

options.label: B
options.text: A law predicts the results of certain initial conditions, while a theory tries to provide the most logical explanation about why things happen as they do.

options.label: C
options.text: A law is a scientific idea that has been widely accepted, while a theory is a scientific idea that has been widely rejected.

options.label: D
options.text: A law is a scientific idea that has been proven to be false, while a theory is a scientific idea that has been proven to be true.
